description: From Middle English infatuate (“foolish”, adjective), from Latin infatuātus, past participle of infatuō.

adjectives.description: infatuate (comparative more infatuate, superlative most infatuate)

examples: Helas I lamente the dull abuſyd brayneThe enfatuate fantaſies the wytles wylfulnesOf on and hothyr at me that haue dyſdayne

[…]  she has a number of relations here, brothers and cousins, by the dozen; but they are all priests, and I am apprehensive that some of these infatuates may persuade her to quit me, and lock her up in a convent  […]

verbs.description: infatuate (third-person singular simple present infatuates, present participle infatuating, simple past and past participle infatuated)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To inspire with unreasoning love, attachment or enthusiasm.
examples: I declare the girl seems quite to infatuate the men, and see if trouble does not come of it.
[…]  wee beggard our selues by hearkning after false riches, and infatuated our selues by hearkning after false knowledge.
